intro: Macaranga necopina, commonly known as the white-veined macaranga, is a flowering plant species native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its alternate, simple, and often hairy leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in clusters, which are typically borne on short pedicels. Its latex is milky and copious, a common feature among members of the Euphorbiaceae family. Macaranga necopina is often found in lowland and hill forest areas, thriving in humid and shaded environments.
